I further recommend that those who check out the site for Wiener's new book at http://hnn.us/articles/9216.html also read Prof. James Lindgren's post regarding the book and follow the links he provides there. You will learn a great deal about the scandal surrounding Arming America, and how Bellesiles was able to feed his flawed work, hook, line, and sinker, to those who overlooked its falsifications because the thesis agreed with their own personal views of gun control.
 
 A central theme to Arming America was the claim that there were very few guns around when the nation was founded. The claim is that gun ownership only became widespread after industry proved capable of mass marketing them decades later. The research Bellesiles provided in his work was quickly used to bolster the "collective right" view of the RKBA under the guise that if there were very few guns around at the time then the Founders must not have intended the 2nd. A to recognize an individual RKBA. Central to Bellesiles' thesis was his research into probate records of the time, in which he claimed to have found very few guns listed. The book received rave peer reviews from supporters of gun control, like Gary Wills, who said the following:
 
 "Bellesiles has dispersed the darkness that covered the gun's early history in America. He provides overwhelming evidence that our view of the gun is as deep a superstition as any that affected Native Americans in the 17th century."-Garry Wills, New York Times 11. Garry Wills, Editorial, Spiking the Gun Myth, N.Y. TIMES, Sept. 10, 2000, § 7, at 5. (Wills subsequently withdrew his support for the work once Bellesiles' research came under fire, and to his credit he candidly admitted that that he had been duped by what he felt to be the plausibility of the book's thesis)
 
 Problems with Arming America were first brought forward by Clayton Cramer, who still deserves the majority of the credit for exposing problems with Bellesiles' work. However, in addition to being decidedly pro-gun, he is not a "professional" historian. Therefore, others who are professionals entered the fray. 
 
 Prof. Lindgren is one of those. He is also someone who dislikes guns and has mostly written on the side of gun control. He attempted to reconstruct some of Bellesiles' anti-gun research into probate records in Providence, and he proved that the records Bellesiles claimed to have discovered either did not exist or, when found, showed that guns were actually plentiful despite his claims. He also cites the work of other historians (Robert Churchill, Joyce Malcom, Randolph Roth, Ira Gruber, Gloria Main, and Justin Heather) who collectively devastate Bellesiles' work.
 
 In Lindgren's post you will also see his view on the now-famous episode of Bellesiles' use of San Francisco probate records. In Arming America, Bellesiles cited probate records from San Fran which he claimed to have found in the clerk's office of the San Francisco Superior Court, but which in fact did not exist because they had been destroyed in the fire following the great quake of 1906. When that scandal broke (by the Boston Globe) Bellesiles' was unable to produce records of his research. He claimed his records were all destroyed in the now dubious and oft-changed story of the "great Bowden Hall flood" at Emory University, where he maintained his office. Nevertheless, Bellesiles rushed off to try and find something he could claim were San Francisco probate records to defend his research. Everywhere he went, however, he discovered that no one had copies of the destroyed records. 
 
 In the end, he did find some probate records that had the words "San Francisco" mentioned somewhere in them. He found these records in San Fran's neighboring Contra Costa County at the Contra Costa History Center (CCHC). Although these turned out to be Contra Costa County probate records, and not San Fran records, Bellesiles nevertheless changed his story to claim that these were the San Fran records he was citing, and that he had actually found these records at the CCHC (and not the San Fran courthouse) during his original research. He then claimed he was only innocently mistaken when he cited to San Francisco probate records in Arming America. Yet, these records did not correspond to what he used in his book. Additionally, the staff at the CCHC later cast serious doubt on whether he had ever been to the Center before his hurried trip after the San Fran records issue arose. Bellesiles tried to downplay the effect of criticism from the CCHC staff by making comments that the staff was not even aware of what they had in their own library. Bellesiles' conduct so embarrassed his university that Emory sent the CCHC a formal letter of apology for his remarks. 
 
 Within Lindgren's post at the http://hnn.us/articles/9216.html site you will find his discussion of this and other problems with Bellesiles' research, as well as links to two other professors' views on the San Francisco records debacle. Those professors are Jerome Sternstein (who has been very critical of Bellesiles) and Jon Wiener (who has always publicly defended Bellesiles and whose book about Bellesiles, Lott, and others is being reviewed at the HNN site).
 
 Why is any of this important? Because Bellesiles' flawed research is still being peddled in court actions, even after these problems surfaced. The most blatant use after the scandal broke was by the 9th. Circuit's majority in its opinion in Silviera v. Locklear. The majority still chose to use the research, but in light of the scandal it dropped the cite to Arming America and instead reverted to cite an original rough draft of Bellesiles' research which was published in a history journal.

 I came out of law school in 1993. Sadly, the Second Amendment was ignored in my constitutional law class. All law professors have the ability to structure their curriculum, but I think the 2nd. Amendment is largely ignored in law schools because there is just not a lot of law out there on it (in the sense of current give and take changes like you see with the 4th. Amendment or, more recently, the 8th. and juvenile capital crimes). No one I know who is a lawyer can remember the Second Amendment getting any serious discussion as part of their con law classes. I remember our focus in con law (as far as the BoR was concerned) was on the 1st, 4th., 5th., 6th., 8th. 9th., and 10th. The 2nd. only became discussed as part of Justice Black's theory that the 14th. totally incorporated the BoR as enforceable against the states. 
 
 I did get a lot of history on our civil liberties in law school, and the 2nd. was mentioned there as an individual right we inherited from English tradition (principally, from the English Bill of Rights, which arose from the "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 against the Catholic restoration monarchy). Here is an archived quote of that document:
 
 "That the raising or keeping of standing armies in the kingdom in time of peace, unless it be with the consent of parliament, is against law."
 "That the subjects which are protestants may have arms for their defense suitable to their conditions, and as allowed by law."  
 
 Here is an archived quote from Blackstone explaining how the RKBA contained in that document was interpreted:
 
 "The fifth and last auxiliary right of the subject, that I shall present mention, is that of having arms for their defense, suitable to their condition and degree and such as are allowed by law. Which is also declared by the same statute W & M st. 2.c.2. [ie. The Bill of Rights] and it is indeed a public allowance under due restrictions, of the natural right of resistance and self-preservation, when the sanctions of society and laws are found insufficient to restrain the violence of oppression. In these several articles consist the rights, or as they are frequently termed, the liberties of Englishmen. . . .
 And we have seen that these rights. . .consist, primarily, in the free enjoyment of personal security, of personal liberty, and of private property. So long as these remain inviolate, the subject is perfectly free; for every species of compulsive tyranny and oppression must act in opposition to one or other of these rights. To preserve these from violation, it is necessary that the constitution of parliaments be supported in it[s] full vigor. . . .And lastly, to vindicate these rights, when actually violated or attacked, the subjects of England are entitled, in the first place, to the regular administration and free course of justice in the courts of law; next to the right of petitioning the king and parliament for redress of grievances; and lastly, to the right of having and using arms for self preservation and defense." Sir William Blackstone, 1 Commentaries on the Laws of England, p. 136 & 140 (1st. ed. 1765, reprinted 1979).
